review_title: Great place with a great mission and awesome values!

job_title: Graphic Design Coordinator in Omaha, NE
pros: They stand for good. I love that they advocate for those with IDD. They have their own department for that. They believe in growth mindset.
cons: They don't advocate for their own employees. I often felt like they were belittling me. The leaders were stuck in a process, and didn't want to veer from that even slightly. New ideas were not welcomed. So much for growth mindset. I wish they had a few of those that have IDD on their board. How wonderful it would be to hear from them. They discuss diversity and inclusion, but most of their staff are white females. I worked from home, and found myself working more than being in an office. They are open to their employees picking up kids, and what not. There are times where you will work straight through lunch. That's commonplace.

pros: Mosaic does important work, and I truly believe the intent behind the company is good. The majority of people who work here, especially as you move up the ladder, care about the people we serve and helping them live full and fulfilling lives. Working for Mosaic gives you the opportunity to directly impact the lives of other people in a way you may not be able to elsewhere. Working with the individuals we serve can be very fun and life-affirming. There is no doubt that the work you do matters and makes a difference. You're not just another cog in the wheel.
cons:
Staff morale among direct support staff seems low. There are frequent call-offs and constant scrambling to fill scheduled shifts. There is a lot to be done on a shift, and almost all of it is crucial/important, so it can be overwhelming trying to learn everything that needs to be done and getting it all done within your shift. Caring for other people can be very physically demanding.

There doesn't appear to be a comp time structure for salaried employees. So any extra hours you work are just bonus for the company. If you are short for any reason, you must use PTO. Holidays are somehow mandatory, yet unpaid. Prime example of when you must use PTO. This structure is unlike anything I've seen at any other job, and it definitely leaves me feeling unappreciated and taken advantage of.

review_title: A Great Vision Which is Poorly executed
pros:
- Create genuine and meaningful connections with the people who are served. 
- Provide unique experiences/opportunities for those who may not have otherwise experienced them. 
- Fairly autonomous in work. Management isn’t breathing down your neck to accomplish tasks.
cons:
-Management/Supervisors work from home and are disconnected from needs of staff and clientele
- Will use phrases such as “we have big plans for you”, “you’re going to get supervisory positions”, “Mosaic really treats their staff like family”, to ensure longevity of lower level staff
- Barely above minimum wage for non-supervisory employees
- Bureaucratic environment causes clientele to suffer unnecessarily 
- Clear and obvious divide between supervisory positions and Direct Support Staff creates an atmosphere of animosity and disrespect
- Corporate office in Nebraska is disconnected from needs and operations of national branches

cons: no concerns as of right now

review_title: Agency is going through a financial constraints
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Antonio, TX
pros: Agency has flexible schedules and you work enough during the week, you don't have to use PTO for time off.
cons: The agency is struggling to get through.  There are cuts being made on all levels, so there is no guarantee that you will have a long career with the agency.  As far as staff, there is a shortage.  The agency has burned bridges with direct care staff, that the word is that no one wants to make a career change because the uncertanity of the agency.  The agency also lacks consistency and formal systems.  Management is not involved at the direct care level and the ultimate focus is MONEY and the level of care questionable.  Please be careful on being poached and lured into a position before you leave your current position.  The money is great, but your time there will be miserable and the demands are ridiculous, especially when the agency does not have it "together" and expect you to be a "top of the line" supervisor/manager.  You are alone and there is no support.  Management is always looking to "pin" the blame on someone and long term staff there act like they do not know anything or its their first time hearing of it (although they have been there for 10+ years).     This is a faith-based agency, but I will tell you it is the worse group of people you can work with, FAKE.  BE CAUTIOUS !!!

review_title: It's all good. . . until it's not
job_title: Direct Support Professional in Papillion, NE
pros: I really like the clients. Many of the direct support care workers are caring and thoughtful and in this field for all the right reasons. Unfortunately, many of the nurses and managers are lazy and don't support the people who do all of the work.
cons: Absolutely no support for direct care workers. They fired the best employee at our house for no reason, with no evidence, because a crazy nurse accused him of something he didn't do. If someone like him can be fired, everyone else should worry. We're talking about someone who never called in, was never late, went above and beyond the job requirements. Poof! One day he was gone because he tried to get first aid for a client in the house, and the nurse accused him of all kinds of things. Easier to fire him and keep the nurse, right? Our house hasn't been the same since he left, and now the rest of us know to watch our backs around that nurse. The environment is awful.

pros: You get to help people.

job_title: Direct Support Associate in Omaha, NE
pros:
Rewarding to work with great clients.
Pay is better than some agencies
cons: When I  first went to work with Mosaic five years ago I was impressed with the company. They were religious based and the word integrity was their by word. What a turnaround.  Direct care staff are not appreciated or respected.Many hard working caring staff are fired for made up reasons. The turn over rate is  off of the charts. Look at the statistics. Many incompetent managers are promoted or recycled to other departments. In the five years I worked for Mosaic we had seven different  managers at the same site . Making money appears to be the main focus of the company, The Liberty program is their new priority, Very few clients are capable to work in this program. OTC was eliminated at  the Workshop at J Street East. The clients there could do this job and were very proud of their work.  They now just sit all day with no work they can do. How sad for people who cannot speak for themselves.   Several long term people in higher management positions have already left. What does this tell you.

pros: I absolutely loved working with the clients that I did. It was a handful at times but we really grew to connect and communicate.
cons:
Its so terribly hard to feed another person when you arent given the means to feed yourself. I saw almost all of my coworkers succumb to mistreatment at one point or another because of the tremendous burden this instills. I dont know one coworker who wasnt morally convicted and truly only there because of the love for clients.
 When this is a daily reality: feeding others when you cant afford food, taking them to events that you cant personally afford, etc., you begin to wonder whether their mission is heartfelt. 
 I never compromised the dignity of my clients, and am pretty versed in dealings with working with people with I.D.'s. However i felt stripped of my dignity several times by higher ups (who never seem to interact or care for the people we served). They would come and talk to me about my clients as if they were inanimant objects that couldnt hear, feel, think, or make choices on their own. Discouraging but only serves to solidify the conviction in my life.

pros: Your life will never be the same. The clients are amazing. No matter how crazy or stressed you are at the end of the day your clients mean everything to you. The benefits are great if you are single. Not so great for a family but certainly competitive. Lots of professional development opportunities. This company is very mission and values lead. You know exactly what the culture is and how to fit in. They do an excellent job training and keep up with technology and best practices. Something that most competitors do not do. Great support from the National Office.
cons: Wages are lower than many other companies and the opportunities for increases are very limited due to the budgetary constraints by the state. I do believe they would pay more if they could. Opportunities to move up are also limited and I'm not sure why. Turnover can be painful at this company, especially in the management area. Work life balance is hard for certain positions. It is very easy to get burned out at this company though they are very generous with PTO.

pros:
- Everyone I work with is focused on their daily work
- Many of the senior leaders including the CEO and COO worked their way up from the entry level position so they know the challenges 
- Senior leadership is very open and friendly.  From the CEO to the direct care management
- Free health insurance program for employees at the lowest tier, has saved my wife and I money
- Great opportunities to do and try different things in your field since in some positions  you are the only person in your job title across the entire organization
cons: As a non profit the usual stuff applies.  Sometimes you have to do things outside of your regular job to pitch in in different areas even though they are completely unrelated to your regular job duties.

pros: Most of the staff are there for the right reasons. They care about the people we serve and are genuine.  Spending time with the people served is rewarding.
cons: The Director is toxic and often lies and manipulates staff. She is out for herself and has made it clear that she isn't there to make friends. She rarely helps with anything and is basically pulling a paycheck. She leaves for days with out anyone knowing where she is. Her passive aggressive attitude and the way she talks down about people behind their backs, is disturbing. The turnover rate is unbelievable. The house managers work 100s of hours a week with out any support or help from the Director. They have closed down the only thing some of the people they serve had to look forward to and the only way they could make money. They do not live the mission. It's all money and how much they can cut instead of giving meaningful lives.

review_title: Disorganized Business that abuses their employees
job_title: Direct Support Associate in Forest City, IA
pros: The hours are flexible if you are hired on as a sub. This allows you to have more control over your schedule, or work during the summer months if you are a student.
cons:
If you are part time or full time there is no flexibility with your schedule. They are constantly short staffed, and holes are left on the schedule until the day of. If they are unable to find staff to cover those shifts staff are forced to stay and work until a replacement can be found. This leads to 16 hour days, which is impossible for anyone who has kids or attends school. This also happens too often to be considered a rare occurrence. 

This makes the job a place where staff dread coming in because they do not know if they will be able to leave. Staff cannot plan a life outside of work, which leads to a quick burnout rate for employees. 

They also only offer annual raises that are 2% of your gross income. This will barley cover inflation, therefore staff make less the longer they work here. 

Due to staff shortages they will search for managers from outside of the company rather than promoting staff that have worked there for years.

pros: Clients are a joy to work with and make it worth coming to work each day.
cons: Throwing people under the bus for personal gain is never a good quality.  Our management needs to pull their heads out and realize that we have people working for personal gain and do not care at all about the clients or host homes.  Some have even gone so far as to intimidate clients that are their own guardians to say things that are untrue regarding their providers.   They do not care about the truth.  I strongly urge others who have worked or are working for Mosaic to bond together for the good of our clients that we serve.  You need to post your experience on this web site so we can get the attention of management.

job_title: Direct Support Associate in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Once you get the hang of it, the job gets much easier. You have training for two weeks and get your CPR/First aid certifications. If I could give anyone advice, get in to this job get through the training period and then quit.
cons: The turn over rate is so high that there are people constantly in and out of the company. The higher ups don't expect you to stick around long and treat you with little respect. The management and HR department in the Colorado Springs location have poor communication skills and seem to care little about their Direct Support Associates. Along with the low pay, this job is only for those who REALLY need it since it is fairly easy to get the job.

pros: "Embracing God's call to serve in the world, advocates for people with intellectual disabilities and providing opportunities for them.
cons: Manager clicks that literally make things ups at the expense of workers, host providers, and few good first level managers. People lose their jobs if they don't go along with the click.  A lot of manipulation of clients, especially those who are their own guardians in order to prevent them from moving out of services to other providers. So opposite of their mission statement and for a religious based organization there is no encouragement for clients to seek spiritual avenues.  No doubt, what is happening is not what the founders had in mind.

review_title: Second Review in addition to "get in and get out".
job_title: Direct Support Associate in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: The clients are the absolute best to work with, the hardest part about leaving this job is leaving these wonderful people behind to some uncaring next employee. After working with the same clients for now just over a year and a half I will be sad to leave them and happy to leave the company.
cons: Do NOT try to voice your opinion. It will not be heard and your suggestions will be seen as threats to management. They do not want you to make the place better, they want to keep it how they have made it and soak in it. Clients do not have the supports they need, management does not care about their social needs. If medications are passed and people are changed then management is satisfied. This company will see its downfall as soon as the providers see what they are wasting their money on.

pros: Clients are the best part but little contact if you want career advancement with clients and then it's just another job with mismanagement of resources and priorities.
cons: Very little career advancement and no career path.  Poor management.  Transition in current structures leaving staff disgruntled and more work put on lower paid staff.  Currently cutting lower and middle management structures and hiring VPs.  Tenured employees offered uncertain positions then cut.  Upper leadership gap and out of touch with direct care needs.  No unemployment, no cobra, no matching 403 b.  Should not be considered a serious interest for anyone valuing benefits or long term supports from employer.

pros: Good pay if you're going to school. Not for long term.
cons:
-Awful Management: Management Postions and others require degrees, yet very few actual have degrees to be doing what they're doing.
- No follow through with anything.
- If you want to take PTO, might as well forgot about it if your manager is out of the office or on vacation, which is at least for a week once or twice a month. No PTO allowed to be taken if manager is away.
-Count on doing part of the managers jobs. Examples: Making important calls to guardians about things a manager should be discussing, filling shifts for the manager, because they don't have the schedule with them every.
- If you're part time they will expect you to fill shifts, but neglect to give you any full time benefits if you're working over 64 hours.

job_title: Direct Support Associate in Terre Haute, IN
pros:
The clients/residents I worked with were great.
People generaly respect the kind of work you do (care for the disabled)
Insurance
Full time is 32 hours
cons:
There seems to be a lot of hostility within the Terre Haute Branch of Mosaic. I can't speak for any of the other branches.
The only reason to stay or go back is the clients. 
Pay is insulting.
(I started at $8.00 hr we recived a company wide raise making starting salery for a DSA (Direct Support Associate) $8.32 I recived two raises in 2.5years so my ending salery was $8.75. I hear that if you have your CNA you get $1.00 more an hour)

mosaicinfo.org

review_title: What you expect from Direct Care
pros: Lots of paid training, love the clientele, pretty good benefits after a year, service, overtime (though frowned upon), wide range of shifts available
cons: If replacement does not show up, you're basically stuck there unless an on-call worker actually says YES when called, no matter how long you've been there... Direct care can be emotionally and mentally exhausting. Low wages and other budgetary issues working in non-profit agency. Trainers and office staff are often condescending and judge without ever actually working direct care. Management and the whole company go on about caring about the clients, but at the end of the day its a business and they will condense these people into fewer and fewer homes when budget requires it...despite negativity toward institutionalization...seems pretty similar to me. Problematic with changing budgets, etc meaning quality of care and amount company really cares about its clients is going downhill

job_title: Direct Support Associate in Nevada, IA
pros: You get to work with amazing individuals , create friendships, enjoy the community and have a set schedule.  You are encouraged to get out and do things outside of the home you work in
cons: The communication at this job is very poor.  Upper management seems unorganized and fails to inform employees of upcoming events/training until the last minute.  Frequent policy changes.  Management state they take direct support staff concerns seriously, but follow through states otherwise.  Management does not respect the time of others, they're more concerned with getting shifts covered so they do not have to fill in and work them.

review_title: Good place to work to start a career
pros: Good learning environment for those beginning a career because you are forced to learn quickly as most agencies are small and you are responsible for decisions made in that agency.  Work schedules are flexible and the company has a good work/life balance.  Excellent benefits package. Very high job satisfaction level because of what the company does for the community.
cons: Very poor professional salaries because it is a non-profit organization.  Even lower than some comparable non-profit groups.  Dealing with some agency issues can be difficult for young professionals just out of college with little experience.

pros: Okay pay, chance of overtime, a job that requires minimal effort if you're lazy, there really isn't anything else. Insurance sucks.
cons: Don't work here if you value the disabled community. Workers are trash that only come for money. Awful to clients, steal from clients. Management doesn't care and people never get punished for actions. But management is so quick to write you up and fire you for speeding on van. Most houses are disgusting, bodily movements all over bathroom. Workers are verbally abusive and sometimes physically abusive to clients yet when reported management does not care. Disgusting upper management policies.

review_title: Put major emphasis on Intensive Care Facility at the expense of vocation workshops and residential homes.
job_title: Direct Support Associate in Omaha, NE
pros: I love being able to work with the wonderful individuals that Mosaic serves.
cons: Mosaic brought on the responsibility of bringing  individuals from Beatrice State Developmental Services and other higher needs people.  They invested a lot of financial, management and employee resources in funding and staffing these homes.  Currently they are unable to be accrediated by the state of Nebraska.  Meanwhile many vocational workshops and residential homes and under staffed and underserved for intervention hours.  The quality of care has decreased dramatically in the established areas of Mosaic services in hopes of trying to be accrediated in other areas.

review_title: My experience at Mosaic Life Care was eye opening, humbling, and life changing. Super friendly work environment.
job_title: Direct Care Provider in Beatrice, NE
pros:
•You get to see how much it means to a resident who has a intellectual disability just to see you walk in to work for the night.
•The dependency your residenta have on you to be the best you
•The bonds and friendship you gain with resident and Co-workers
•How much happiness and silliness the resident's bring to your life.
•The activities and the community events that Staff gets to take their resident's too.
cons:
•You need to be prepared for anything to go wrong.
•Not getting too attached to a resident
•Very strick rules that must be followed and can cause you to lose your job in seconds; it seems like.
•Residents dying
•Its a exhausting and sometimes frustrating time in certain situations

job_title: Supportive Employment Specialist in Kansas City, MO
pros: Mosaic serves people with developmental disabilities in day and residential programs.  This, in and of itself, is rewarding.  Everyday was different, there was always something new to do or some new challenge to overcome.  I felt as if I made a difference in people's lives.
cons: I was not provided with the tools necessary to fulfill the job requirement.  The position required more responsibilities than one person can do and unreachable goals are set.  When these goals and responsibilities are not met, staff are punished and provided with little to no support.

pros: Mosaic is in a time of positive change across the organization.  Some outstanding key leaders have been hired within the past few years who are now free to make change under our COO who joined in the past year.  It is becoming a completely different work environment from when I started but for the better.  Alot of investment in technology has also occurred and is streamlining processes.
cons: For professional roles, there are not many duplicated positions so that can make it difficult when you are out of the office.  You are not disturbed, but it feel

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: The persons being served are amazing, as are the staff members. The Mission of the organization is very noble. The work is emotionally gratifying.
cons: Management is out of touch with the needs of the staff. Towards the end of my time there, money became more important than the needs of the people being served. Key staff were let go, making other positions incapable of handling the workload.

review_title: Great Job, Amazing People, Strong Mission
job_title: Community Relations Officer in San Angelo, TX
pros: Absolutely loved the people I worked with and for. Made it easy to carry out the mission. Lots of support and training for my position.
cons: Recently, the organization has become very focused on the bottom line, which has made it harder to focus on fulfilling the mission. There is a very specific fundraising model, and veering from it in any way creates dissension.

pros:
Rewarding work with adults with intellectual disabilities

Executives make company-wide changes too frequently
Executives make decisions without keeping in mind the needs of the Direct Support staff
High rate of burn out
Direct Support staff are underpaid and undervalued

job_title: Direct Support Associate in Des Moines, IA
pros: the clients are the best part of this company
cons: the management are very rude and disrespectful. always under staffed because they treat their DSA's horrible. they are constantly calling all day. they aren't willing to work out a schedule with people that are going to school. pay and benefits aren't worth the crap you put up daily with. management forgets that for clients to be happy so do the staff, we work with clients daily and they see when we aren't happy. the recent changes in polices and management make it even worse then when i started. i received less then 2days of in home training then was yelled at when something wasn't done correctly. i regret ever working here. it has been a horrible experience.

review_title: Disorganized, if you don't like it, they can replace you, no worries.
job_title: Direct Support Associate in Omaha, NE
pros: You get to help people with disabilities live lives to the fullest.
cons: Bad frontline management, in part because they work their managers to death for little pay. Promotions chosen by who you know not how your qualified. Once you reach coordinator level there is apparently no accountability and you can do whatever you want.

review_title: Best place to work for listening to worker say I love and enjoy this make me cry to know I feel the same
job_title: Home Health Caregiver in Nevada, IA
pros: Being able care care for clients, understanding there needs and want spending time with them and getting to know them helping clients to having a better life and knowing they have someone that they trust.
cons: Change staff, clients not having see the same staff all the time.

pros: Great pay and benefits are pretty good.
cons: A certain manager will blame you for having poor time management even though it's not the DSP's fault that they don't have enough staff. They want 1 person to get a huge list of things to do, including getting 6-8 clients up, bathed(same manager said they HAVE to be done in the morning) and dressed, breakfast has to be made, and meds distributed and they give you from 5am-7/7:30am to get all this done. He told me not to mop bedrooms until clients leave but then he wrote me up because I didn't have the floors done before the shift was over.

pros: Individuals we serve are wonderful people to work with and know.

review_title: A joyful place to work your very hardest!

Love for the clients and selfless service carries them through.  Due to the highly regulated environment of care, when human error occurs at any level, the front line staff get  disciplined.

review_title: Mosaic supports there clients, not there staff
job_title: Direct Support Associate in Coventry, CT
pros: been working for the company for almost 7 years, i work at a great house, with great clients and great staff, if it weren't for the good clients i would have left my job years ago,
cons:
never got a raise from the company in the almost 7 years, only a 1% raise from the state, minimum wage is increasing and soon we will be at it. 

The GPS in car, if you accidently go over the safe mileage you get hit with a write up, If you are more the 3 minutes late you get a write up, you have to dress nice even tho you will be giving baths and showering people, and cleaning toilets and bleaching, there should be something you can wear to protect your cloths

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Forest City, IA
pros: There is an ability to pick up lots of hours. I was working doubles for 3 months straight. The clients you will be helping appreciate you. They usually can't say it but you can tell.
cons: They over work you. They are so under staffed it's not even funny. If you ever want a day off do not work here. On your days off you are put on the on call list and they always call. They don't appreciate you at all. All they see is a body. It's also very physical instead of hiring a physical therapist like they should they expect staff to do things that a therapist should be doing. It's not really the place to work if you have children.

review_title: Great company to work for if you can stand the constant change
pros: Mosaic provides a fulfilling job to those who have the heart to work with people with intellectual disabilities.  They offer generous PTO, a free health plan, and on-going training.  There is never a dull moment.  Front line staff have opportunities to take clients on major trips that will be once-in-a-lifetime experiences for the individuals in service, such as Six Flags, concerts, museums, etc., all free of charge to the employee.
cons: Poor communication starting from the national level and trickling its way down.  Efforts to improve leadership are being made, however, the culture and buy-in necessary to make them a reality are low.  High turn over rates in most agencies leave front-line workers exhausted, and both front and middle management staff overloaded and burnt out.

pros: Mosaic is a wonderful company to work for, they are dedicated to providing individualized, quality supports to the individuals that they support.  Mosaic is always progressive and forward thinking in an ever changing industry.  Mosaic is constantly seeking feedback from its employees to make Mosaic an even better place to work.
cons: The funding that Mosaic receives as a non profit, is a challenge, however, Mosaic continues to provide outstanding supports and services despite this adversity.

pros: The main office management folks are very kind and helpful. And by the end of your training period, you obtain skills that help you on the job as well as everyday life.
cons: Working overnights, there’s an 8 hour span where you have to attempt to keep yourself busy because all of your clients are usually in bed and sleeping is frowned upon.

job_title: Community Relations Manager in Dallas, TX
pros: The people the organization serve are located at the administrative office.
cons: Very short sighted outlook on actual business decisions. Training at the onset of the job was very spotty and building a cadence for on-boarding/training was not a priority. Clarity in role is another area to improve upon. There seems to be a lack of explicit expectations for events and what is asked upon you. There is a lack of belief in growth and meeting structure is really awful. Team meetings were archaic at best. There were no strategic conversations around growth plans or

pros: Excellent staff and home managers.
cons: Executive director and upper management in Dallas are dangerously unaware of state HCS and ICF regulations.  Executive director has made decisions that negatively effect the company without consulting those involved, or who may know how to handle these situations.  This has included pursuing a restraining order against a person actively living in one of the homes owned by Mosaic, and releasing an employee of 20 plus years due to "their position being discontinued".  Turnover rates are through the roof, case managers are hourly employees but are expected to work off the clock.  Employment opportunities for those in Mosaic's care have been discontinued with minimal options filling these places.

pros: Working for an organization that provides services to people with intellectual disabilities. It was nice to know that I contributed to helping people
cons: Poor management, disorganization at the corporate level, poor communication from the top down, lack of support at the corporate level.

review_title: I enjoy working with most of my coworkers and managers

The enivronment will be very crowded, loud and overstimulating to our individuals who have autism and are very sensitive to noise and high levels of aggressive behaviors.

Making a difference

pros: This is an excellent job opportunity for people who have a big heart and a nurturing spirit. Mosaic provides services to individuals with developmental disabilities. If you want to make a positive impact in someone's life, employment here pays in ways that really count.

pros: I have learned so much about myself just by working at Mosaic. Working with people with disabilities has been the highlight of my life. It has prepared me for the highs and lows of life. cons: Pay is lower than other agencies in the area.

pros: Wonderful clients, great staff, descent benefits for hourly employees.   If you had a good group of people in your house things can be great when you work together.
